711367f-a.text:
West 16th Street, looking east from 6th Avenue.
(Before Reconstruction).

President Borough of Manhattan.
November 21, 1918.

711411f-a.text:
119-145 West 17th Street, North side, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.
about 1922.
Edwin Levick.

711365f-a.text:
West 16th Street, south side, east from, but not including Sixth Ave.  Shown on the right, is a portion of St. Francis Xavier College.  Demolition further eastward is that of the former New York Hospital.
April 3, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709369f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue at N. E. corner of 17th Street.
March 22, 1935.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

709369f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue at N. E. corner of 17th Street.
March 22, 1935.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

709367f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from W. 16th Street, showing the vicinity that was for a period the shopping centre. Under construction underground is the new municipal subway.

The "El" structure at this date is being demolished. The station of same is at 18th Street where Siegel-Cooper and B. Altman held sway on opposite sides of this thoroughfare. The latter occupied the structure on the west side from 18th to 19th Streets.

This building appears at the left center of View No. 2, being photographed from 17th Street. An article on this subject appeared in the New York Times of March 7, 1939 titled "122 Year Holding is Sold on Sixth Avenue."

February 19, 1939
Views: 1-2
P. L. Sperr

Same as view 1, after demolition of "El."
P. L. Sperr         October 26, 1939

709674f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, at the S. E. corner of West 16th Street, showing the Greenwich Savings Bank. Adjoining same to the east is St. Francis Xavier R. C. Church and College.
May 17, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709366f-a.text:
6th Ave., w.s., at 15th St. March 29, 1939
P.L. Sperr, photographer

709368f-a.text:
6th Avenue, southwest corner and 17th Street.
P. L. Sperr  March 29, 1939

711364f-a.text:
West 16th Street, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Sixth Avenue, showing St. Francis Xavier R.C. Church and College. The latter is housed in the low structure on the left. It is a Jesuit Institution, opened in 1847, and chartered in 1861. About 1895.
Gift of Urbrook Collection.

1558012.title: 582 Sixth Avenue - West 17th Street
1558012.folder: 582 Sixth Avenue - West 17th Street, Manhattan, NY

709364f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, from W. 16th to 17th Streets. A parking lot occupies the northerly half of this frontage: this being the S. E. corner of 17th Street. The two buildings remaining are at the N. E. corner of 16th Street. View 3 being of an earlier date shows four buildings there. Two of these were subsequently demolished. The towering loft structures are on the side streets, backing up to each other through the block.
Views 1,2: May 17, 1939
View 3: April 3, 1935
P. L. Sperr

709371f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north across West 17th Street. The gas station appearing is at the S. E. corner. This permits details of buildings at the S. E. corner to be clearly observed. View No. 3 is limited to this corner.

The earlier view is photographed during the period while the old 6th Avenue "El" darkened the Avenue. View 2 is taken immediately after demolition of same.

The ornate structure above 18th Street is the former Siegel-Cooper Department Store. This institution widely published the phrase "Meet me at the fountain." This was derived from the presence of a magnificent interior fountain and stairway. During the World War, (1917-18) this structure was utilized as a hospital.

April 3, 1935
March 29, 1939
May 17, 1939

P. L. Sperr
